newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine wheat sowing boosted by rain -- Sparks.
newsitem.headline: Argentine wheat sowing boosted by rain -- Sparks.

text.p: Heavy rain throughout much of Argentina's wheat belt Sunday and Monday improved prospects for farmers preparing to sow their 1997/98 crop, a Sparks South America official said Monday.
"This should mean that the planned sown area should not fall," Sparks South America Vice-president Juan Martin Rebolini told Reuters.

Argentina's more northerly crop lands -- in northern Buenos Aires, Santa Fe and Cordoba -- have been dryed out by a lingering drought. Sowing of longer-cycle wheat in northern areas is due to start later this month, but much of the sowing in the south takes place in July.

Rebolini said that rainfall had varied considerably in different crop zones Sunday. About 60-100 millimeters fell in northern Buenos Aires, but only 19-25 millimeters fell in the south of the province, which is Argentina's main wheat area.
He said falls of 30-50 millimeters had been recorded in Entre Rios, but very little rain fell in Cordoba and Santa Fe.

"But it was raining last night in Santa Fe, so those figures might have changed," Rebolini said, "Mind you, even if it rains 40 or 50 millimeters we'll still need quite a bit more rain for soil moisture to recover completely."

He said that rainy weather was forecast to continue up till Thursday. Longer-term forecasts predicted normal rainfall in most of key Buenos Aires province during June and July, but less than normal falls in the north of the province.
Rebolini said in April that Sparks expected Argentina's wheat area to fall by 10 percent from 1996/97, leading to production of 12.7-13.3 million tonnes in normal conditions.
Farmers sowed 7.2 million hectares last season, and produced a record 15.8 million tonnes.
Sparks South America is the local office of U.S. agricultural consultant Sparks Companies, of Memphis, Tenn.
